async_info.video_title: Barnier: Brexit Deal is result of 'intensive work' - BBC News
async_info.video_description:
The EU's chief negotiator Michel Barnier tells the press conference there are four main elements to the part of the Brexit deal concerning Northern Ireland:
The island will remain aligned to a limited set of EU rules, meaning goods will be checked on entry to the island, rather than across a border on the island Northern Ireland will remain in the UK's customs territory, benefiting from the UK's future trade policy. but it will also remain an entry point into the single market Mr Barnier did not go into detail about what has been decided about VAT - a key sticking point of the deal for the DUP - but he says: "On this point also we have maintained the integrity of the single market but also satisfied the UK's legitimate wishes" Four years after the enforcement of the deal, the elected representatives of Northern Ireland will be able to vote on whether or not to keep the arrangements in place "Discussions over the past days have at times been difficult, but have delivered and we have delivered together," Mr Barnier says.
"What really matters [in Northern Ireland] is peace," he adds.

comment_content.original_script:
Boris's Brexit deal is going to be passed by Parliament. Because . . . .This new plan will keep only Northern Ireland closely aligned with the EU rules, specifically on goods.
This avoids any checks on the island of Ireland, though checks will still have to happen on goods moving to or from the island of Ireland from the rest of Britain. But CRUCIALLY,
the whole of the United Kingdom — including Northern Ireland — will get to leave the EU customs union. The arrangements are kind of complicated — for example, the UK will have
to apply and collect EU tariffs if any goods going from the rest of Britain are at risk of entering Ireland, otherwise known as EU territory. However, leaving the EU customs union
means that the whole of the United Kingdom will be free to negotiate new trade deals with countries outside the EU. This is a massive improvement over Mrs May’s proposed deal.

async_comment.comment_content_initial: Boris's Brexit deal is going to be passed by Parliament. Because . . . .This new plan will keep only Northern Ireland closely aligned with the EU rules, specifically on goods. This avoids any checks on the island of Ireland, though checks will still have to happen on goods moving to or from the island of Ireland from the rest of Britain. But CRUCIALLY, the whole of the United Kingdom — including Northern Ireland — will get to leave the EU customs union. The arrangements are kind of complicated — for example, the UK will have to apply and collect EU tariffs if any goods going from the rest of Britain are at risk of entering Ireland, otherwise known as EU territory. However, leaving the EU customs union means that the whole of the United Kingdom will be free to negotiate new trade deals with countries outside the EU. This is a massive improvement over Mrs May’s proposed deal.

We haven't seen the bill yet. Or the concocted explanation of why there should be one. They have been pushing this idea that there is 'supposed to be' a bill, for so long, that people have come to believe there must be a reason for it. There is: To take advantage of us.
Why should the money be going in THEIR direction? Why not to US? For all the years of delay in them getting round to making a trade deal with the US, for example. Where we were forbidden from making one ourselves. And for 40 years of bailing out the French farming industry to keep the tractors off the Champs Elysée, and putting up with the French pompously declaring themselves to have a bigger economy than the UK (because we were SUBSIDISING it).
They will want us to just write a blank cheque.
You want a trade deal? Another cheque please.

comment_content.original_script:
The US and the UK and the EU have their tax havens. People in glass houses should not throw stones. There is one street in Delaware where 140,000 businesses are registered. This was pointed out to Obama when he wanted to go after British tax havens.
What the EU will do: Once we are out, they will declare that it is not safe for the EU to have its financial centre in an independent country with its own currency. They will then move to establish their OWN financial centre.
If we had stayed in, they would eventually have done this anyway, as we do not use the Euro. So, in or out, we are screwed.
You can complain all you like about the City of London. But it is responsible for a significant part of the nation's income and tax-take.
OTOH the City has been an obstacle to the building of a stronger manufacturing economy because the best and brightest went into the City for the big bucks. There are people who say the future of First World countries is to hand over such menial work as manufacturing to 'inferior' countries/peoples. This is dumb. They will eat us for breakfast. We need to manufacture stuff ourselves. Germany does. And look at its financial situation: Surplus. Not deficit.

comment_content.original_script: This is literally just the beginning. Whats become distorted over the last 3 years due to the UKs rediculious amount of BS, dithering & contrarianism is the fact this "deal" isent a deal its just the withdrawal agreement. If the UKgov. hadn't descended into 3 years of self absorbed navel gazing & tantrum throwing, this WA should have been agreed within the first month of negotiations. Now its on to the actual trade negotiation. Which there is now 14 months to discuss. At which point if the UK hasent a WTO schedule sorted(which it probably wont, Russia took 17 years to gain approval after USSR fell & could trade on the old out of date one which the UK cant after the transition period) means that it will take hit an economic wall hard after loosing access to 60 trade deals 749 other treaties. If it matches all of those(which it wont) & gets a trade deal identical to EU membership(which it wont) then it breaks even.
